question:
Type: Shuttle
Debut: September 1976
 Retirement: October 1977
Description: It was flown only within Earth's atmosphere, during Shuttle approach and landing tests conducted in 1977.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: April 1981
 Retirement: February 2003
Description: It flew the first five Shuttle missions, and was modified to fly extended-duration missions as long as 16 days. It and its seven-member crew were lost during reentry on Feb. 1, 2003.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: April 1983
 Retirement: January 1986
Description: It was built as a vibration-test vehicle and then upgraded to become the second operational Shuttle. It and its seven-member crew were lost in a launch accident on Jan. 28, 1986.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: August 1984
 Retirement: March 2021
Description: Atlantis followed it closely in October 1985.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: October 1985
 Retirement: July 2021
Description: It closely followed Discovery (August 1984). It was the last to be retired, ending the Space Shuttle Program.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: May 1992
 Retirement: June 2021
Description: Built to replace Challenger, it made its debut with a dramatic mission that featured the rescue of a stranded Intelsat 6 commercial communications satellite.

Type: Program
Start: 1958
First Crewed Flight: 1961
End: 1963
Number of Missions: 6
Notes: First U.S. crewed program

Type: Program
Start: 1961
First Crewed Flight: 1965
End: 1966
Number of Missions: 10
Notes: Program used to practice space rendezvous and EVAs

Type: Program
Start: 1960
First Crewed Flight: 1968
End: 1972
Number of Missions: 11
Notes: Landed first humans on the Moon

Type: Program
Start: 1964
First Crewed Flight: 1973
End: 1974
Number of Missions: 3
Notes: First American space station

Type: Program
Start: 1971
First Crewed Flight: 1975
End: 1975
Number of Missions: 1
Notes: Joint with Soviet Union

Type: Program
Start: 1972
First Crewed Flight: 1981
End: 2011
Number of Missions: 135
Notes: First missions in which a spacecraft was reused

Type: Program
Start: 1993
First Crewed Flight: 1994
End: 1998
Number of Missions: 11
Notes: Russian partnership

Type: Program
Start: 1993
First Crewed Flight: 1998
End: Ongoing
Number of Missions: 65
Notes: Joint with Roscosmos, CSA, ESA, and JAXA; Americans flew on Russian Soyuz after 2011 retirement of Space Shuttle

Type: Program
Start: 2011
First Crewed Flight: 2020
End: Ongoing
Number of Missions: 6
Notes: Current program to shuttle Americans to the ISS

Type: Program
Start: 2017
First Crewed Flight: 2023
End: Ongoing
Number of Missions: 0
Notes: Current program to bring humans to the Moon again
First person to walk on the moon as commander of the Apollo 11 mission - "That's one small step for man, and one giant leap for mankind". He previously also flew on Gemini 8.
First American woman in space
First human to journey in space - Soviet Air Force pilot, orbited Earth once on April 12, 1961 aboard the Vostok 1 spacecraft
First person to complete a spacewalk - a Soviet on March 18, 1965 after exiting Voskhod 2
First African-American woman to travel in space
First American astronaut to orbit the Earth
First astronaut to spend a full year in space, commander of the International Space Station (ISS) during that time
First spacecraft launched into space - done by the Soviet Union on October 5, 1957
Commander of the ill-fated Apollo 13 mission on April 11, 1970. It was supposed to be the third manned moon mission. Tom Hanks played him in the movie of the same name.
Lunar Module Pilot on the Apollo 11 mission along with Armstrong and Collins. Conducted experiments and collected samples with Armstrong on the surface.
Command Module Pilot on the Apollo 11 mission along with Armstrong and Aldrin. Remained in orbit around the Moon until the other two returned.
First American astronaut to travel in space on May 5, 1961. He also piloted a Mercury spacecraft (Freedom 7) on a suborbital flight. He commanded the Apollo 14 mission in 1971.
